repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
utf8proc contains all the data which is currently in
unicode_tables.generated.h internally, but in quite a different format.
Ideally unicode_tables.generated.h should be removed as well so we rely
solely on utf8proc. We want to avoid a situation where the possibility
of unicode mismatch occurs, e.g a distro using both unicode 12 and
unicode 13.

comment_data.body:
German sharp s upper case at home: ẞ

I.e., the whole rationale for this custom function is wrong now -- uppercase ß was added in 2017 -- so we should just use `utf8proc_islower`.

I think I'll leave this alone in this PR. The reason is that what is considered uppercase/lowercase depends on user options, and I don't want to mess with them yet. I think it'd be best if we isolated the removal later.

This one doesn't, though -- it's hardcoded, and wrong. I'm just saying keeping _this_ special behavior is not worth it and shouldn't block a change you would otherwise want to make (even if you want to keep the `keepascii` option, which I agree makes sense).
Oh, you mean remove just the `|| a == 0xdf` part? Yeah, we could do that. Wonder if we should send PR to vim, this sounds relevant for them as well.
I don't think they have the tables for that ;)

comment_regular_data.body: For reference: This would close multiple open issues about ZWJ and emoji modifiers not being supported, and likely simplify our mbyte.c spaghetti.
Is there anything preventing us from merging this. I don't think utf8proc is a risky dep.
ye, we were mainly waiting for branching 0.10 before. fine to merge this and iterate during the 0.11 cycle.

> Is there anything preventing us from merging this. I don't think utf8proc is a risky dep.

I'm not even sure if we want to use utf8proc. This was a prototype to get it up and running so we could experiment on it to determine if we think it's good enough. Otherwise there are other libraries that we can try as well like libgrapheme.

If we're fairly sure this is good for us then we can merge it.

> I'm not even sure if we want to use utf8proc. 

Tmux uses it so it must be good. Also utf8proc in tmux fixed a bug for me once: https://github.com/tmux/tmux/issues/3365

libgrapheme is probably at least worth considering. From [their page](https://libs.suckless.org/libgrapheme/):

>Some libraries, like libutf8proc and libunistring, are incorrect by basing their API on assumptions that haven't been true for years (e.g. offering stateless grapheme cluster segmentation even though the underlying algorithm is not stateless). As an additional factor, libutf8proc's UTF-8-decoder is unsafe, as it allows overlong encodings that can be easily used for exploits.

Smaller and simple build systems are nice plusses too.

Some useful context: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=33612039

> > I was hoping for some alternative since the linked article mentions utf8proc as such:
>>
> > > Some libraries, like libutf8proc and libunistring, are incorrect by basing their API on assumptions that haven't been true for years (e.g. offering stateless grapheme cluster segmentation even though the underlying algorithm is not stateless). As an additional factor, libutf8proc's UTF-8-decoder is unsafe, as it allows overlong encodings that can be easily used for exploits.
>
> There is a stateful API too, and I'm surprised they mention it's decoder is unsafe, utf8proc is fuzzed by oss fuzz, which I assume would catch something like that.

This also caught my eye:

> > I was just thinking how convenient it is to type emojis right into strings in Python and print them. I assumed C didn't have much unicode compatibility, though I didn't research it.
>
> Libgrapheme is a nice library, but it doesn't really have anything to do with this.
>
> Almost all modern terminal emulators use the UTF-8 character encoding. In order to successfully output Unicode characters, your programming language doesn't actually need much "Unicode support"; it just needs to be able to send UTF-8-encoded bytes to stdout. (That's why many modern programming languages like Go and Zig define strings as a simple array of bytes.) Modern C compilers allow you to printf("é") and get the appropriate behavior.
>
> As you mention, the terminal emulator also needs to be able to decode and display those UTF-8 bytes correctly, and a lot of terminals don't get it right in some situations. Off the top of my head, I don't know of a terminal that actually implements the entire (very complex) set of Unicode text rendering behaviors; maybe one of the web-based ones that run in Electron? macOS's Terminal.app is also pretty good IIRC.
>
> Where libgrapheme comes in is if you want to analyze or manipulate a UTF-8-encoded string. It provides operations like "split into words" and "convert to uppercase". A surprising number of programs never need to do that stuff, but if you do, libgrapheme will give you a Unicode-compatible implementation. (Many more basic operations, like concatenating two strings, will work just fine without libgrapheme.)

Which suggests to me it doesn't quite meet our needs.

It being Suckless also puts me off.

My opinion should be weighted very lightly since I'm not involved in the encoding side of Neovim very much.

>Off the top of my head, I don't know of a terminal that actually implements the entire (very complex) set of Unicode text rendering behaviors [...] macOS's Terminal.app is also pretty good IIRC.

[🤦](https://mitchellh.com/writing/grapheme-clusters-in-terminals#terminal-comparison)

> Smaller and simple build systems are nice plusses too.

Libgrapheme doesn't have a "simpler build system" in a way that benefits us. What they mean is "we use make and not cmake", which for us means more work integrating it. Not saying libgrapheme isn't worth it, just this point is false.
Let's go with utf8proc for the time being. It is early in the development stage and it's good to gather user reports early if something doesn't seem to work.

title: build: add utf8proc as dependency
